security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based methodology skill. All 138 static findings are false positives triggered by documentation examples showing legitimate shell commands for debugging (echo, env, grep, git commands). The single bash helper script (find-polluter.sh) is a transparent local test bisection tool with no network access, credential handling, or persistence mechanisms. No malicious intent detected.

content.user_title: Find root causes before fixing bugs
content.value_statement: Random fixes waste time and create new bugs. This skill provides a four-phase framework to systematically investigate issues, trace problems to their source, and implement fixes that actually resolve the underlying cause rather than masking symptoms.
actual_capabilities: Four-phase debugging framework: Root Cause Investigation, Pattern Analysis, Hypothesis Testing, and Implementation
Root cause tracing technique to trace bugs backward through call stacks to find original trigger
Defense-in-depth validation patterns for adding validation at multiple system layers
Condition-based waiting patterns to replace arbitrary timeouts with polling
Test pollution detection using bisection script to find which test creates unwanted state
Anti-pattern recognition to avoid common debugging shortcuts that cause rework
limitations: This is a methodology skill - it guides problem-solving but does not execute code fixes automatically
Requires user to follow the process steps; the skill cannot force compliance
Does not provide debugging tools for specific languages or frameworks
Assumes user has access to codebase and can run tests independently

use_cases.title: Debug test failures

use_cases.title: Investigate production issues

prompt_templates.title: Start debugging
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the systematic-debugging skill to investigate this issue. Follow the four phases: Root Cause Investigation, Pattern Analysis, Hypothesis and Testing, and Implementation. Do not propose any fixes until you complete Phase 1 and understand the root cause.

prompt_templates.title: Test failure
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply systematic debugging to this test failure. First, reproduce the failure consistently. Then trace the data flow backward through the call stack to find where the invalid data originated. Document your findings before attempting any fix.

prompt_templates.title: Flaky test
prompt_templates.prompt: Use condition-based waiting techniques from systematic-debugging to fix this flaky test. Replace arbitrary timeouts with polling that waits for actual conditions. Run tests to verify reliability.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-layer bug
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply root cause tracing to trace this issue through all system layers. For each layer boundary, add diagnostic logging. Then apply defense-in-depth validation at every layer the data passes through.

output: Phase 1: Investigating root cause
- Error message: Connection timeout to payments.api.com
- Pattern: Occurs during high traffic periods
- Recent changes: Last deploy 2 days ago
- Hypothesis: Connection pool exhausted under load
Phase 2: Finding patterns
- Working services use connection pooling with retry
- This service has no retry logic
Phase 3: Testing hypothesis
- Added connection pool metrics
- Confirmed pool exhaustion at 1000 concurrent requests
Phase 4: Implementing fix
- Created failing test case for pool exhaustion
- Added connection retry logic with exponential backoff
- All tests pass, issue resolved

output_examples.input: Tests are failing because a .git directory appears unexpectedly
output: Phase 1: Root Cause Investigation
- Symptom: .git directory appears in project root after tests
- Reproduced: Runs in clean checkout, appears after npm test
- Used find-polluter.sh to identify culprit test
Phase 2: Pattern Analysis
- 1847 tests use Project.create() with temp directories
- One test passes empty string for workingDirectory
Phase 3: Hypothesis Testing
- Empty string resolves to process.cwd() for git init
- Confirmed: git init runs in source directory
Phase 4: Implementation
- Added validation at 4 layers (entry, business, environment, debug)
- All tests pass, bug structurally impossible

best_practices: Always complete Phase 1 (Root Cause Investigation) before attempting any fix, even under time pressure
Trace problems backward through the call stack to find the original trigger, not just where symptoms appear
Add validation at every layer data passes through (defense-in-depth) to make bugs structurally impossible
anti_patterns: Quick fixes without investigation - this guarantees rework and new bugs
Skipping root cause analysis because the issue seems simple
Trying multiple fixes simultaneously - you cannot isolate what works

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with all programming languages?
faq.answer: Yes. The debugging methodology is language-agnostic. The principles apply to any codebase regardless of language or framework.

faq.question: How long does the full four-phase process take?
faq.answer: For simple bugs, 5-10 minutes. Complex issues may take 30-60 minutes. This is faster than the hours of rework from symptom fixes.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with existing debugging tools?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill complements your existing tools. Use your IDE debugger, logging, and test frameworks while following the systematic process.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my codebase?
faq.answer: No. The skill provides guidance and prompts. It does not automatically write or modify code. You implement the fixes.

faq.question: What if I cannot reproduce the issue consistently?
faq.answer: The skill addresses this in Phase 1. Gather more diagnostic data, add logging, and use bisection testing to isolate conditions that trigger the issue.

faq.question: How is this different from test-driven development?
faq.answer: TDD focuses on writing tests before code. This skill focuses on investigating existing bugs. Phase 4 references TDD for creating failing test cases as proof of reproduction.
